awd_titl_txt: Engaging Underrepresented Populations in Biodiversity Sciences: A Series of Workshops for Undergraduate Students
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to engage undergraduates, especially those from underrepresented groups, in a discussion on opportunities in biodiversity sciences thru a series of workshops, mentoring, and shadowing activities. Emerging global issues, such as climate change, loss of biological diversity, land and water resource conservation, and sustainable agriculture, require more reliance on a workforce with training and expertise in biodiversity science. Four workshops will be conducted over a 4-year period to increase the number and diversity of undergraduate students interested in pursuing careers in biodiversity science (including collections science and organismal, evolutionary, ecological, and environmental biology). Student recruitment will target students from local community colleges, minority-serving institutions, and four-year colleges and universities. Professional societies will also be enlisted to recruit Native Americans, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders, African Americans, and Latino American students to participate in two-day workshops hosted by natural history museums. Undergraduate students participating in the workshops will be exposed to emerging careers and research opportunities by: (1) shadowing museum professionals to get hands-on experience in collections science; (2) learning about research and career opportunities from diverse graduate students and early career professionals pursuing careers in biodiversity science; and (3) getting practical advice and individualized mentoring to navigate their undergraduate experience and optimize their potential for graduate school and careers related to biological sciences, museum studies, and biodiversity collections. 

Across a broad range of scientific disciplines, diversity in research scientists has provided new perspectives and ideas leading to novel solutions and increased productivity. This series of workshops will work to recruit, retain, and sustain a larger, more inclusive, and diverse, undergraduate population of students equipped to engage in creative solutions for emerging science questions. Workshop activities will introduce underrepresented populations of undergraduate students to natural history museums, biodiversity collections, and collections-based researchers as a means to inspire and educate them in opportunities and data rich resources in biodiversity science.

por.por_cntn:
In a concerted effort to promote diversity and inclusivity within the biological sciences, a series of workshops across the United States have been instrumental in providing invaluable experiences to aspiring biologists and biodiversity scientists from underrepresented populations. The primary goal was to immerse those in attendance into the world of research and museum work, offering insights into the pathways leading to these careers. Workshops, with the exception of the one held at the California Academy of Sciences, spanned two days. The first day contained a shadowing event. During this session, participants had the unique opportunity to step into the shoes of museum and research professionals, gaining firsthand experience of a typical day in these professions. This immersive approach allowed students to witness the challenges, routines, and responsibilities inherent in the field, providing valuable insights into potential career paths. The second day featured a diverse array of activities designed to enrich the participants' understanding of the biological sciences. The day comprised engaging speakers, enlightening museum collections tours, a thought-provoking panel discussion, and a meet and greet session with local professionals. These components were meticulously curated to offer a comprehensive view of the multifaceted nature of careers in biology and biodiversity science. The speakers brought their expertise to the forefront, sharing valuable insights and experiences from their respective journeys in the field. Topics covered included a detailed guide for applying to graduate school and opportunities for students funded by the National Science Foundation. The museum collections tours provided a behind-the-scenes glimpse into the vast repositories of knowledge that these institutions hold, showcasing the significance of research and curation in advancing our understanding of the natural world.


A pivotal component of the workshops was the panel discussion, where participants had the chance to interact with seasoned professionals. This interactive session facilitated conversations about the challenges, opportunities, and various career trajectories available in the biological sciences. The meet and greet segment further fostered networking opportunities, allowing attendees to connect with local professionals, paving the way for mentorship and future collaborations. A notable highlight of each of the workshops was the participants' enthusiastic engagement with professionals, displaying a keen interest in seeking advice and networking opportunities. Their proactive approach in seeking contact information and expressing interest in future interactions underscored their dedication to pursuing careers in the biological sciences. The first workshop was held at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County in Los Angeles, California on April 6 and 7, 2018. The Museum of Northern Arizona in Flagstaff, Arizona hosted the second workshop on October 12 and 13, 2018. The third workshop took place on November 8 and 9, 2019 at the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science and the Museum of Southwestern Biology, University of New Mexico in Albuquerque, New Mexico. The National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, hosted the fourth workshop on April 21 and 22, 2023. The last workshop was held in conjunction with the annual meeting of the Society for the Preservation of Natural History Collections at the California Academy of Sciences on May 29, 2023. This 1⁄2 day workshop, entitled Diversity and Identity in Biodiversity Science Careers, was open to LGBTQIA2+ individuals and allies including local college and university students and emerging professionals. Those attending listened to a series of talks by invited speakers in the LGBTQIA2+ community discussing their biodiversity science career pathways. They were then able to interact with the speakers and each other during a panel discussion on the intersection of identity and science and during a reception.


These workshops have been pivotal in engaging over 350 undergraduate students from underrepresented populations, igniting their interest in biodiversity science careers. Through immersive experiences like shadowing museum professionals and engaging workshops with keynote speakers, panel discussions, and networking sessions, these events have offered invaluable insights into the diverse pathways and opportunities within biodiversity sciences. They've provided a platform for students from underrepresented backgrounds to interact with professionals, fostering mentorship possibilities and empowering them to envision a future in this field. The hands-on nature of these workshops, coupled with proactive engagement opportunities, has inspired these students, encouraging their pursuit of careers in this field by breaking down barriers and creating a more inclusive and supportive environment within biodiversity sciences.
